customer_name: TIGERS FOR TOMORROW EXOTIC ANIMAL PRESERVE IN
site_name: TIGERS FOR TOMORROW EXOTIC ANIMAL PERSERVE INC

citations.narrative:
The facility has recently obtained ten wolf-dog hybrids who have large shelter structures in their outdoor enclosures. The
openings to the shelter structures do not contain a wind/rain break. A wind/rain break is necessary to provide shelter from
the elements for the wolf-dogs. The facility shall ensure that the shelter structures for the wolf-dogs are provided with a
wind break and rain break at the entrance.

The facility has recently obtained ten wolf-dog hybrids who have ample room in their enclosures for exercise. The facility
has not yet documented their plan to provide the wolf-dog with exercise or had the attending veterinarian approve the
plan. Adequate exercise is necessary for all dogs for their health, muscle tone and well-being. The facility shall document
their exercise plan in writing and have the attending veterinarian approve the plan.

The facility has recently obtained ten wolf-dog hybrids. The attending veterinarian has not developed, documented in
writing, and signed a program of veterinary care specifically for these dogs. A program of veterinary care specific to the
wolf-dogs is necessary to address the requirements for their adequate veterinary care including regularly scheduled visits,
annual physical exams, vaccinations, sampling and treatment for parasites and pests, and preventative care/treatment for
hair coats/nails/eyes/ears/skin and teeth. The attending veterinarian shall develop, document and sign a program of
veterinary care for the wolf-dogs.

The facility has recently obtained ten wolf-dog hybrids. The wolf-dogs have not yet each had a documented complete
physical exam from head to tail. Regular physical exams are necessary to document the physical condition of each wolf-
dog to maintain their health. The facility shall keep a record of the exam findings. The facility shall have the veterinarian
complete a physical examination from head to tail for each wolf-dog.

Two outdoor housing enclosures are not enclosed by an appropriate perimeter fence.
*One enclosure housing one Geoffrey cat is enclosed by a perimeter fence but the perimeter fence lacks sufficient height
around one side and the front of the enclosure. The perimeter fence along those two sides is only 4.5 ft in height rather
than the required 6 ft in height.
*One enclosure housing two Capybara has a 6 ft high perimeter fence for the back side of the enclosure, a 4. 5 ft high
perimeter fence for one side of the enclosure (side adjoining barnyard area), a 4 ft high perimeter fence along the front of
the enclosure and no perimeter fence on the second side of the enclosure (side near office).
A perimeter fence is required to keep out unwanted animals and unauthorized persons and to act as a secondary
containment system for the animals housed in the facility.
The facility shall ensure that the Geoffrey cat and Capybara outdoor enclosures are enclosed by a perimeter fence that is
no less than 6 ft in height and is located greater than 3 ft in distance from the primary enclosure or shall receive approval
in writing from USDA Animal Care.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by 60 days counted from 1st RL Inspection or the applicant
will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-
License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.4(b)(3) 
   
Outdoor housing facilities. 
The facility has recently obtained ten wolf-dog hybrids who have large shelter structures in their outdoor enclosures. The 
openings to the shelter structures do not contain a wind/rain break. A wind/rain break is necessary to provide shelter from 
the elements for the wolf-dogs. The facility shall ensure that the shelter structures for the wolf-dogs are provided with a 
wind break and rain break at the entrance. 
3.8 
   
Exercise for dogs. 
The facility has recently obtained ten wolf-dog hybrids who have ample room in their enclosures for exercise. The facility 
has not yet documented their plan to provide the wolf-dog with exercise or had the attending veterinarian approve the 
plan. Adequate exercise is necessary for all dogs for their health, muscle tone and well-being. The facility shall  document 
their exercise plan in writing and have the attending veterinarian approve the plan. 
3.13(a) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility has recently obtained ten wolf-dog hybrids. The attending veterinarian has not developed, documented in 
writing, and signed a program of veterinary care specifically for these dogs. A program of veterinary care specific to the

wolf-dogs is necessary to address the requirements for their adequate veterinary care including regularly scheduled visits, 
annual physical exams, vaccinations, sampling and treatment for parasites and pests, and preventative care/treatment for 
hair coats/nails/eyes/ears/skin and teeth. The attending veterinarian shall develop, document and sign a program of 
veterinary care for the wolf-dogs. 
3.13(a)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The facility has recently obtained ten wolf-dog hybrids. The wolf-dogs have not yet each had a documented complete 
physical exam from head to tail. Regular physical exams are necessary to document the physical condition of each wolf-
dog to maintain their health. The facility shall keep a record of the exam findings. The facility shall have the veterinarian 
complete a physical examination from head to tail for each wolf-dog. 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
Two outdoor housing enclosures are not enclosed by an appropriate perimeter fence.  
*One enclosure housing one Geoffrey cat is enclosed by a perimeter fence but the perimeter fence lacks sufficient height 
around one side and the front of the enclosure. The perimeter fence along those two sides is only 4.5 ft in height rather 
than the required 6 ft in height.  
*One enclosure housing two Capybara has a 6 ft high perimeter fence for the back side of the enclosure, a 4. 5 ft high 
perimeter fence for one side of the enclosure (side adjoining barnyard area), a 4 ft high perimeter fence along the front of 
the enclosure and no perimeter fence on the second side of the enclosure (side near office).  
A perimeter fence is required to keep out unwanted animals and unauthorized persons and to act as a secondary 
containment system for the animals housed in the facility.  
The facility shall ensure that the Geoffrey cat and Capybara outdoor enclosures are enclosed by a perimeter fence that is

no less than 6 ft in height and is located greater than 3 ft in distance from the primary enclosure or shall receive approval 
in writing from USDA Animal Care. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2  more inspection(s) or by 60 days counted from 1st RL Inspection or the applicant 
will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-
License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
